Hydrogen production from catalytic steam reforming of biomass compounds represents an alternative to the growing demand for new renewable energy sources. In this work, highly stable Ni catalysts synthesized by exsolution method from LaNi0.38B0.62O3 ±δ-type perovskite with different cations at the B site (B= Ti, Al, Fe) are described. These catalysts were evaluated in hydrogen production from steam reforming reaction using ethanol, a typical oxygenated molecule derived from biomass that is commonly used for this reaction. XRD analyses confirmed the formation of perovskite-like structures and the exsolution of Ni metallic particles after reduction treatment. In addition, XPS results demonstrated surface enrichment of Ni(0). The catalysts that exhibited greater stability in 24 h tests were those reduced at 750 °C, from LaNi0.38Ti0.62O3-δ and LaNi0.38Al0.62O3-δ perovskites, the catalyst with Ti in B-site being the most stable with no signs of deactivation throughout the whole reaction. Moreover, this catalyst maintained a constant activity during 100 h of TOS, a very low carbon deposit formation rate, and showed a high capacity to remove carbon deposits via gasification, compared to reported catalysts not based on noble metals. The high stability observed in this catalyst was related to the strong metal-support interaction generated during the metal catalyst preparation process from the exsolution method. Graphical Abstract Keywords LaNi0.38B0.62O3±δ-type perovskite catalysts Exsolution method Ethanol steam reforming Strong metal-support interaction Stability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to the rapid growth of society and the global economy, primary energy sources such as coal, oil, and natural gas, are expected to remain the dominant energy source (82 %) for the next 15–20 years [1,2]. However, this dependence on fossil fuels has led to a significant increase in the accumulation of CO2 in the atmosphere and an unavoidable depletion of fossil fuel reserves. In fact, the longer society delays adopting decisive actions to sustainably reduce emissions, the greater the resulting economic costs may be. The technologies required to achieve decarbonisation primarily point to renewable energy sources, including wind, solar, biofuels, and blue and green hydrogen. Among these alternatives, hydrogen has emerged as one of the most promising options because it can be obtained from sustainable resources, is not site-specific, and is a clean energy carrier since it only produces water vapor when consumed in a fuel cell. Among the different existing methods for hydrogen production, natural gas steam reforming is one of the most widely used; however, fossil fuels are not a renewable source and aggravate the energy crisis. In this sense, ethanol constitutes a good alternative as a raw material since it can be obtained from biomass as a renewable source [3]. Thus, ethanol can be produced through bioprocesses such as the fermentation of sugars derived from cellulose or lignocellulosic biomass residues, called second-generation ethanol. Likewise, ethanol can be obtained from biomass residues subjected to thermochemical treatments [4] or through the fermentation of anhydrous sugars generated during the pyrolytic processes [5]. In recent years, the scientific community's efforts to use biomass-derived molecules for hydrogen production have significantly increased. [6–9]. In particular, ethanol steam reforming is a well-established catalytic process that has been extensively investigated over the last decades. Ethanol is an oxygenated molecule with a simple chemical structure, which facilitates studying key reaction pathways involved in steam reforming, such as C–C bond cleavage, the water–gas shift (WGS) reaction, and the formation of secondary products. Numerous studies have reported on active catalysts for ethanol reforming and the influence of operational variables, such as temperature, residence time, and ethanol-to-water ratio, on ethanol conversion and hydrogen yield [10–14]. Recent research has focused on the development of stable catalysts under the severe operating conditions of this reaction [15–18]. Steam reforming of ethanol is an endothermic reaction that occurs between 400 and 700 °C (Eq. 1). This reaction generates primarily H₂ and CO₂ along with by-products such as CO, CH₄, and, in some cases, acetaldehyde (CH₃CHO), acetone (CH₃COCH₃), and ethylene (C₂H₄). This is because multiple simultaneous reactions occur in this process, including both desired reactions (Eqs. 2–7) and undesired reactions (Eq. 8–12). Operating conditions and catalyst characteristics favor such reactions; hence, many developments in this field focus on designing efficient and stable catalysts that enhance hydrogen yield and reduce the formation of undesirable by-products. Ethanol Steam Reforming (1) CH 3 CH 2 OH + 3 H 2 O → 6 H 2 + 2 CO 2 , ∆ H 298 ° = 174 kJ mol - 1 Ethanol Dehydrogention (2) CH 3 CH 2 OH → CH 3 CHO + H 2 , ∆ H 298 ° = 68 kJ mol - 1 Ethanol Decomposition (3) CH 3 CH 2 OH → CH 4 + CO + H 2 , ∆ H 298 ° = 49 kJ mol - 1 Water Gas Shift (4) CO + H 2 O → H 2 + CO 2 , ∆ H 298 ° = - 41 . 4 kJ mol - 1 Acetaldehyde Condensation (5) 2 CH 3 CHO → CH 3 COCH 3 + CO + H 2 , ∆ H 298 ° = 4 . 1 kJ mol - 1 CH 4 Decomposition (6) CH 4 → 2 H 2 + C , ∆ H 298 ° = 74 . 8 k J mol - 1 Ethylene Decomposition (7) C 2 H 4 → 2 H 2 + 2 C , ∆ H 298 ° = - 52 . 3 kJ mol - 1 Ethanol Dehydration (8) CH 3 CH 2 OH → C 2 H 4 + H 2 O , ∆ H 298 ° = 45 k J mol - 1 Acetaldehyde Decomposition (9) CH 3 CHO → CH 4 + CO , ∆ H 298 ° = - 19 . 3 kJ mol - 1 Methanation (10) CO + 3 H 2 → CH 4 + H 2 O , ∆ H 298 ° = - 206 . 1 kJ mol - 1 (11) CO 2 + 4 H 2 → CH 4 + 2 H 2 O , ∆ H 298 ° = - 165 . 0 kJ mol - 1 Boudouard Reaction (12) 2 CO → CO 2 + C , ∆ H 298 ° = - 175 . 5 kJ mol - 1 These competing and parallel reactions can be promoted or avoided by carefully optimizing the above mentioned operating variables and/or by tailoring the physicochemical properties of the catalysts and their active phases. For example, methane decomposition and reforming reactions are thermodynamically favored at high temperatures, where the former is undesirable and the latter is a desired reaction. In contrast, the WGS reaction is disfavored with increasing temperature. Side reactions producing carbon deposits (Eqs. 6–7 and Eq. 12) would decrease activity by blocking the active sites or affecting the reactor (pressure drop, heat transfer, crushing the catalyst pellets, etc.). Among the catalytic properties that enhance the performance of catalysts are: (i) the capacity to break C-C bonds, (ii) high metal dispersion or small metal particle sizes, (iii) high oxygen mobility, (iv) controlled acid-base properties, and (v) strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [19,20]. While the former properties are primarily associated with catalytic activity, the latter property, a priori, is closely related to phase stability since if a strong metal-support interaction exists, sintering of the metal phases could be avoided during reforming. Ni-based metal catalysts have been highlighted within the catalysts evaluated in steam reforming of ethanol (ESR) for their high capacity to break C-C, C-H, and C-O bonds and their economic feasibility [21–23]. However, it exhibits limited resistance to coke formation, so the effect of different supports, promoters, and second metal addition to overcome its deactivation issues has been thoroughly studied. Supports based on the use of simple oxides such as Al2O3, La2O3, CeO2, ZrO2, and mixed oxides, spinels (for example, aluminates), perovskites, and layered-double hydroxides, among others [19–21,24–33] have shown the ability to increase oxygen mobility as well as to facilitate the H2O adsorption and to enhance metal-support interaction, thus improving the catalysts performance. Besides, stability of the catalysts is related to their resistance to the formation and removal of carbon deposits, which are a common cause of deactivation. Reports show related factors that modify the activity and/or stability. In this context, Osorio-Vargas et al. [25] reported that the stability of Ni catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 was sharply enhanced with the addition of 15 wt% La2O3 and 10 wt% CeO2, and they obtained a decrease in carbon deposition rate of 72 % compared to the unpromoted catalyst. The promoters favored the removal of carbon deposits through the lanthanum oxycarbonate formation and a greater oxygen mobility induced by the CeO2 promoter. The same authors reported an increase in stability with the addition of Rh to this Ni catalyst [26]. In the same sense, Greluk et al. [27] improved dispersion of active phase and the metal-support interaction by using different solvents and organic compounds during the catalyst synthesis, such as water, ammonia, or citric acid. Here, edge/steps metallic sites favored C-C bond cleavage and oxygen species transfer from the lattice to the carbon deposits by stronger metal-oxide interactions. Conversely, active sites located on terrace atoms promoted carbon nucleation, requiring larger ensemble sizes, thus demonstrating a dependence between stability and nickel crystallite size. Wang et al. [28] attributed the significant decrease in coke detected on Ni/CeO₂-ZrO₂ catalysts to the SMSI effect. This study employed two synthesis methods to prepare the catalysts: one-pot (hydrothermal) and successive impregnation. The one-pot method resulted in Ni nanoparticles with abundant oxygen vacancies due to the major interaction with the support, favoring coke gasification. Meanwhile, large Ni clusters prepared by the successive impregnation method promoted carbon formation, demonstrating the importance of the SMSI effect on catalyst stability. The SMSI effect was also recently proposed by Meng et al. [29] with RhNi/TiO2 catalysts obtained from RhNiTi-layered double hydroxide precursors. All these studies suggest that the SMSI effect influences both some physicochemical characteristics of the catalysts as well as the activity and stability of the catalysts. In the search for strategies to increase the SMSI effect and thus the catalyst stability, perovskites (ABO3) have gained recognition as catalyst precursors due to their stable structures, flexible physicochemical properties, and ability to accommodate A′ or B′ doping cations. Perovskites as metal catalyst precursors have been evaluated as a method to enhance catalyst stability based on the work proposed by Nishihata et al. [34]. This study demonstrates that a severe reduction treatment of the catalyst precursors results in a system exhibiting both metallic and surface-active phases with a pronounced SMSI effect [34–36]. In this same context, a new synthesis approach known as "exsolution" has emerged to prepare “in situ” supported metal catalysts with more precise nanoparticle size control and enhancing resistance to sintering and carbon deposition by SMSI effect due to the metal nanoparticles' socketing in the host perovskite [36–39]. Exsolution is a chemically driven heterogeneous phase transition process that allows the generation of metallic nanoparticles on perovskite's surface when the material is thermally treated under reducing conditions [40]. For this purpose, the perovskite is commonly doped at the B-site with a reducible transition metal (AB1-xB'xO3), and exsolution of this B′ element occurs through its nucleation and growth when the perovskite is reduced. Neagu et al. [36] reported interesting results demonstrating this behavior on Ni exsolved from La0.52Sr0.28Ni0.06Ti0.94O3 compared to Ni deposited on La0.4Sr0.4TiO3. This latter catalyst coalesced rapidly at temperatures ≤ 800 °C, while the activity of the catalyst prepared by the exsolution method is maintained after 10 h of reaction at 900 °C. This last sample does not show significant changes in particle sizes, demonstrating a good anchoring of the active phases and the perovskite network. In addition, this same catalyst showed significantly less carbon fiber growth, highlighting the unique characteristics of the interface developed between exsolved particles and the parent support. Agüero et al. [41,42] have also reported interesting studies using the exsolution method for preparing metallic Ni catalysts for H2 production through ethanol steam reforming. The authors have demonstrated that this method allows the segregation of strongly interacting nanoparticles after controlled structure destruction, with promising conversion and selectivity. They claim that the purity of the synthesized perovskites is a crucial factor in confirming the inclusion of Ni in the structure and the control of its exsolution during the reduction procedure. In one work, on La1-xCaxAl1-yNiyO3 (x = 0, 0.1; y = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3) perovskites, it was confirmed that the exsolution process resulted in Ni nanoparticles firmly anchored to the perovskite support, which gave stability to the catalysts and excellent activity with low CO and CH4 selectivity, the highest stability shown in this study was about 12 h. Several other studies on catalytic reforming have reported the use of perovskites as metal catalyst precursors, showing Ni nanoparticles highly resistant to sintering and coking, ascribed to a strong metal-support interface formed during the exsolution process [43–47]. This process is influenced by the stability of the doped structure with an easily reducible dopant (e.g., Ni, Co, Pd, Rh, etc.), promoting oxygen vacancies and structural defects and reducing temperature [37,39,40,48–50]. In fact, the vacancies can be a driving force for exsolution since they destabilize the lattice stoichiometry, leading to segregating B-site cations to maintain structural stability. In this context, in this work a series of Ni catalysts synthesized by exsolution method from LaNi0.38B0.62O3-δ -type perovskites (B = Ti, Al and Fe) for ESR to obtain H2 were studied. The influence of the B-site cation on the catalytic performance and stability was systematically evaluated. A comprehensive characterization was performed on both fresh and post-reaction catalysts. For the catalyst exhibiting the highest stability, the effect of operating variables was evaluated to optimize H2 yield. This study reveals the role of the B-site on catalyst stability during the steam reforming for H2 production. Cations with varying reducibility and valence states, such as Ti, Fe, and Al, were used at the B-site. The LaNi0.38Ti0.62O3-δ catalyst reduced at 750°C exhibits high stability and catalytic performance (H2 yield = 52 % with S/C =1.5) during 100 h of time-on-stream (TOS) without signs of deactivation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2⋅6 H2O, Analyticals Carlo Erba, 99 %), titanium isopropoxide (Ti[OCH(CH3)2]4, Sigma Aldrich, 97 %), lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (La(NO3)3⋅6 H2O, Merck, 96 %), anhydrous citric acid (C6H8O7, Parafarm, analytical grade), aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3⋅9 H2O, Anedra, 98 %), iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3⋅9 H2O, Anedra, 98.1 %), ethylene glycol (C2H6O2, Anedra, 99.5 %), absolute anhydrous ethyl alcohol (C2H5OH, Anedra, 99.2 %). All reagents were used without further purification. H2 (99.99 %), Ar (99.99 %), and N2 were provided by Air Liquid. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis LaNi0.38B0.62O3-ᵹ (B = Ti, Fe, Al) perovskites were prepared by a variant of the sol-gel method (Pechini method). A 1.0 M solution of metal nitrates was prepared with deionized water. The metal nitrate solutions were mixed with citric acid in a 5:1 ratio with cations. Then, ethylene glycol was added in a 4:1 molar ratio with respect to citric acid. The solution was stirred for 8 h at 70 °C and then dried for 48 h at the same temperature until a the formation of a dry-gel material. Subsequently, this material was annealed in two stages, first at 300 °C for 2 h and after at 850 °C for 12 h, with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 in an oxidizing atmosphere at ambient pressure. The samples were labeled as LNB, where B = Ti (T), Fe (F), and Al (A). Finally, metal catalysts were synthesized from precursor perovskites by reduction under H2 flow at 30 mL min−1 for 1 h and at two different temperatures, 500 and 750 °C, in-situ before the reaction. The as-prepared catalysts were named rLNBX, where B = Ti (T), Fe (F), Al (A), and X = reduction temperature. In addition, a Ni-supported catalyst was synthesized using LaTiO3 as the support. First, LaTiO₃ was prepared via the previously described Pechini method. Then, a conventional wet impregnation technique was employed to incorporate nickel. For this purpose, an appropriate amount of nickel nitrate (corresponding to 10 wt% Ni) was dissolved and added to the LaTiO3 support. The resulting mixture was stirred for 4 h at room temperature. After impregnation, the sample was dried at 120 °C for 8 h and subsequently calcined at 500 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 10 °C min⁻¹ . 2.3 Precursors and catalysts characterization The specific surface area of perovskites was determined by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms obtained at −196 ºC using Micromeritics equipment, model ASAP 2020, with a previous degasification at 100ºC for 1 h. The specific surface area and pore size distribution were calculated using BET and BJH methods, respectively. Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) curves were obtained with a home-made equipment. In a typical experiment, 30 mg of sample were placed in an electrically heated fixed-bed quartz micro-reactor, and heated from RT to 950 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The reactor was fed with a gas mixture (10 % hydrogen in nitrogen, flow rate 20 mL min−1). Hydrogen consumption was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The precursors' and reduced catalysts' X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was carried out using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm) in a PhillipsPW 1732. The diffraction angle (2θ) range between 5 and 80 º was collected at a scanning speed of 1 º min−1. The HighScore software was used to identify the present crystalline phases, and Rietveld refinement was performed using a Fullprof Suite. The profile peaks were fitted using a Pseudo-Voigt function. XPS experiments were performed on a Physical Electronics spectrometer (PHI VersaProbe II Scanning XPS Microprobe) with scanning monochromatic X-ray Al Kα radiation as the excitation source (200 µm of radius of the area analysed, 25.0 W, 15 kV, 1486.6 eV), and a charge neutralizer. The pressure in the analysis chamber was maintained lower than 2.0 × 10–6 Pa. Spectra were charge referenced with the C 1 s of adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV. Energy scale was calibrated using Cu 2p 3/2, Ag 3d 5/2, and Au 4f 7/2 photoelectron lines at 932.7, 368.2, and 83.95 eV, respectively. The collected XPS spectra were analyzed in detail using PHI SmartSoft software and processed using MultiPak 9.6.0.15 package. The obtained spectra were fitted using Gaussian–Lorentzian curves to more accurately extract the binding energies of the different element core levels. The samples were measured as received in the laboratory, without any special pretreatment. The powder samples were deposited on an adhesive tape covering the entire surface of the sample holder. Raman spectroscopy measurements of the catalyst samples were performed on a LabRAM HR Horiba Scientific spectrophotometer with laser line of 532 nm. The dispersion and metallic area were measured by CO chemisorption using Autochem 2910 apparatus supplied by Micromeritics, which has a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The samples were previously reduced and after that, transferred to the reactor cell. The catalysts were heated at 250 °C in an inert atmosphere for 1 h. Then, the samples were reduced at 500 or 750 °C in a 25 % H2/inert mixture flow for 1 h. After hydrogen purging at 450°C, CO adsorption was realised at 25°C with pulses of CO. The presence of carbon nanotubes in post-reaction samples was determined by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) using a JEOL 100 CX instrument, having a resolution of 6 A and an accelerating voltage of ca. 100 kV. The samples were ground and ultrasonically dispersed in distilled water. To evaluate the content of carbon deposits on the used catalysts, temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) analyses were performed in a TA-50 Shimadzu thermobalance. The oxidation was carried out in the range of 50–750 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The analyses were performed using a mixture of air flow at 40 mL/min and helium flow at 20 mL/min. Approximately 10 mg of catalyst (about one-tenth of the total recovered material) was loaded into the platinum capsule of the instrument for each measurement. Prior to analysis, the entire spent catalyst bed was thoroughly mixed to obtain a representative sample. Each analysis was carried out in duplicate. From the mass loss information as a function of time, the derivative curve (DTGA) was obtained. 2.4 Catalytic reaction test 2.4.1 Catalytic reaction test performed under moderate temperature conditions and low residence time The ethanol steam reforming reaction tests were carried out using 100 mg of catalyst (with a particle size ranging from 0.021 to 0.042 cm) diluted with ground quartz in a ratio of 1:2 in a 1.7 cm ID stainless steel tubular reactor with a coaxially centered thermocouple operating at atmospheric pressure. The fixed-bed reactor configuration is depicted in Figure S1. Before the reaction, the perovskites were in situ reduced at 500 and 750 °C for 1 h with H2 flow (30 mL min−1) and subsequently purged with N2 flow (40 mL min−1) for 1 h. The reaction temperature was 500 ºC for the TOS (Time Of Stream) test, and the mixture of water:ethanol with a stoichiometric molar ratio (3:1) was pumped into the evaporator at a rate of 0.01 mL min−1 using an HPLC pump (YL9110) and 20 mL min−1 of N2 as carrier. The resultant Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) of the total gas mixture was 19475 mL gcat−1 h−1. The gases (H2, CO2, CO y CH4, C2H4) were followed online using two gas chromatographs, Shimadzu GC-8A (Molecular sieve 5 A column), and Carlo Erba FractoVAP (Porapak column), with TCD and FID detectors, respectively. The condensable compounds were condensed and analyzed in a chromatograph SHIMADZU GC-2014 equipped with an FID detector. Ethanol conversion (XEtOH), Hydrogen yield ( Y H 2 ) and selectivity to C-products (CO2, CO, CH4, C2H4) (Si) was calculated as: X EtOH = F EtOH in − F EtOH out F EtOH in x 100 Y H 2 = F H 2 out 6 x F EtOH in x 100 S i = F i out Σ F j out x 100 where F i in corresponding to the molar flow inlet and the F i out is the molar flow in the outlet of the reactor. In practice, achieving a piston flow requires minimum geometrical ratios of Dr/dp and Lr/dp greater than 10 and 100, respectively [51], where Dr and Lr are the diameter and length of the reactor, and dp is the particle diameter. This work verified these ratios, obtaining Dr/dp and Lr/dp ratios of 22 and 867, respectively. Additionally, no significant increases in pressure were observed during all the reactions 2.4.2 Catalytic reaction test performed under varying operating conditions Experiments were conducted to study the effect of operating variables on catalytic performance. The influence of temperature was evaluated at 400, 500, 600, and 700 °C, maintaining a constant GHSV of 19475 mL gcat⁻¹ h⁻¹ . The H2O/EtOH molar ratio was tested at values of 3, 6, and 12, with corresponding GHSVs of 19475, 20081, and 20455 mL gcat⁻¹ h⁻¹ , respectively, at a fixed temperature of 500 °C. Finally, the space-time was analyzed at 500 °C, varying the GHSV to 19475, 38950, and 77900 mL gcat⁻¹ h⁻¹ by adjusting the catalyst mass to 100, 50, and 25 mg, respectively. These experiments were designed to assess the impact of these variables on hydrogen yield and catalyst activity. 2.5 Stability test The activity tests for a long TOS (24 or 100 h) were carried out to investigate the resistance to deactivation of reduced catalysts. The evolutions of CO, CH4, CO2, C2H4, ethanol, acetaldehyde, acetone, and acetic acid were recorded. The reaction was performed using the conditions mentioned above and parameters. The deactivation percent was calculated as follows: % deact = Y H 2 i − Y H 2 f Y H 2 i x 100 Where Y H 2 i is the initial H2-yield in the reaction and Y H 2 f is the H2-yield at the time evaluated. 2.6 Carbon gasification test A carbon deposition gasification test was performed to evaluate the catalysts' gasification capacity. An ethanol steam reforming (ESR) reaction was previously carried out until the catalyst was approximately 50 % deactivated. This occurred after 24 h of reaction at 400 °C. Nitrogen was then purged into the reactor for 1 h to remove residual reaction products. The reactor was then heated from 30 to 600 °C at a rate of 3 °C min⁻¹ under a continuous flow of N₂, and the formation of CO and CO2 was monitored using GC-FID. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization XRD measurements confirmed the formation of perovskite-type structure of as-prepared LaB0.62Ni0.38O3-δ (B = Fe, Ti, and Al) materials, and their lattice parameters were calculated by Rietveld refinement, as shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1. The three materials exhibited good crystallinity and diffraction lines that can be associated with a perovskite phase LaBO3. The tolerance factor t, expressed as t = (rO + rA)/√2(rO + rB) (being rO, rA, and rB, the ion radii of O, A, and B ions) showed values between 0.962 < x < 1.003, which suggests a cubic symmetry or symmetry close to cubic for all prepared materials. As can be seen from Fig. 1(a), the LNT sample showed similar diffraction lines characteristic of cubic perovskite (LaTiO3, PDF 75–0267) at approximately 22.6° (100), 32.3° (110), 39.8° (111), 46.4° (200), 52.1° (210), 57.6° (211), 67.6° (220) 72.3° (221), 76.9° (310). The LNF sample also exhibited a diffraction pattern attributable to the LaFeO3 phase having a cubic structure (PDF 75–0439) with 2θ values around 22.8° (110), 32.4° (110), 40.0° (111), 46.6° (200), 52.3° (210), 57.8° (211), 67.9° (220), 72.7° (221), 77.4° (310). Meanwhile, for the LNA sample, peaks were detected at 23.3, 33.2, 41.0, 47.7, 53.8, 59.3, 69.7 and 74.8º, indexes to (012), (110), (202), (024), (122), (214), (208), (1010) lattice faces of rhombohedral perovskite LaAlO3 (COD 1521190). All observed diffractions were slightly shifted with respect to pure perovskites, which could reflect changes in unit cell volume by adding a dopant. This was confirmed by Rietveld refinement. The refined unit cell parameters and crystal system assigned are summarized in Table 1. The observed lattice parameters changes can be due to both differences in ionic radii between the dopant and the B-site cation (Ni3+: 0.0560 nm, Ni2+: 0.0690 nm, Ti4+: 0.0605 nm, Ti3+: 0.0670 nm, Fe3+: 0.0645 nm, Fe2+: Al3+: 0.0535 nm) and to the presence of oxygen vacancies [41,52]. On the other hand, the XRD patterns do not show diffraction peaks associated with La2O3, Al2O3, NiO, CeO2, or different segregated phases, confirming the perovskite phase as the main phase. All these results indicated an effective doping of the Ni cation in the B-site, giving rise to the formation of LaB0.62Ni0.38O3-δ (B = Fe, Ti, and Al) perovskites. The perovskite crystallite sizes, obtained by the Scherrer's equation, are shown in Table 1. This parameter was calculated from the diffraction line located around 32°, which is the most intense line of the diffractogram. The results indicate that the perovskites contain nanometric crystals whose sizes range between 19 and 26 nm and are similar to some reported in the literature [53,54]. The perovskite containing aluminum at the site B is the one that presented the largest crystal size. The textural properties of these materials ( Table 2) showed that the LNT perovskite presented a surface area at least three times larger (19 m2 g−1) than LNF (4 m2 g−1) and LNA (8 m2 g−1), with an average pore width of 10.4 nm. This could influence the metal exsolution as was reported by Rudolph et al. [55]. All samples exhibited a type IV isotherms (Figure S2), typical of mesoporous materials, according to the classification established by the IUPAC [56]. The synthesized perovskites were subjected to a reduction treatment in H2 at two reduction temperatures to seek differences in the exsolution extent. The minimum temperature was set at 500°C based on previous studies [55,57], and the maximum temperature was set at 750°C based on TPR results, as this is the temperature at which most of the Ni phase is reduced (Figure S3). Fig. 2 displays the XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts. As can be seen, two main phases were detected in the rLNT (Figs. 2a and 2d) catalyst after the reduction treatment at both temperatures. The primary phase remains the perovskite structure (Figure S4a,b), and a minor phase with a small diffraction peak at around 44.4° can be associated with metallic Ni (PDF 004–0850), as reported by other authors [46,52,58,59]. These results demonstrated that Ni ions were segregated from the perovskite structure, forming metal nickel nanoparticles supported on perovskite (Ni exsolved). For the rLNA catalyst (Figs. 2b and 2e), the perovskite structure was also preserved (Figures S4 c,d), but the Ni(0) diffraction line was only observed at the highest reduction temperature (750 °C). However, very small particles undetectable by the technique cannot be ruled out in the catalyst reduced at lower temperature. Conversely, after reduction of the rLNF sample at 750 °C, it was observed that the characteristic diffraction peaks of pure perovskite (LaFeO3) had completely disappeared (Fig. 2c). In this case, peaks related to La2O3 (2θ = 30.0 and 46.1° PDF 01–074–2430), La(OH)3 (15.8, 27.3, 28.0, 31.8, 36.2, 39.5, 42.4, 47.1, 48.7, 49.9, 55.3, 56.4, 57.9, 58.9, 64.1, 72.8 and 77.6° PDF 01–083–2034) and a possible Ni-Fe alloy (2θ = 43.7, 50.9 and 74.7° PDF 47–1417) appear as a consequence of the collapse of the structure, as previously reported [8,58]. At 500°C, the perovskite structure was stable for rLNF (Figure S4e); however, no peaks were detected for Ni metal. The exhibited behavior in materials with Fe in the B-site could be associated with their more reducible nature with respect to the other doping cations, which destabilized the structure. The reducibility of the B-site cations in decreasing order is Fe (ΔrG° =53.8 kcal mol−1) > Ti (ΔrG° =103.3 kcal mol−1) > Al (ΔrG° =241.6 kcal mol−1). Here, an effect of the B-site nature was observed, with Ti favoring Ni exsolution to a greater extent and Fe giving rise to a less stable perovskite. In addition, the results showed that it was possible to accomplish Ni exsolution in the prepared materials while retaining the stable perovskite structure, thus driving a catalyst with Ni nanoparticles supported on the starting perovskite. The Rietveld refinement results (Figures S4 f, g, and h) show a progressive increase in unit cell volume when comparing unreduced samples with those reduced at 500 and 750 °C. This lattice expansion can be attributed to the formation of oxygen vacancies under reducing conditions, commonly referred to as chemical expansion [60,61]. The removal of oxygen ions from the crystal structure results in an increase in the Coulombic repulsion between positively charged B-site cations, contributing to the lattice expansion [62]. In addition, this expansion may also arise from the exsolution of metallic Ni during reduction [60,61]. Upon reduction, Ni2+ ions (ionic radius ∼0.69 Å) are partially reduced to Ni(0) (atomic radius ∼1.63 Å) and exsolved from the perovskite lattice, inducing structural rearrangements and an increase in lattice parameters [61]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses of the reduced samples (rLNF, rLNT, and rLNA) were performed to investigate Ni surface species' surface composition and their chemical state. The C 1 s, O 1 s, Ni 2p, Ni 3p, and La 3d core level spectra were studied. Signals corresponding to B-site cations (Al 2p or Fe 2p or Ti 2p) were also studied. For all catalysts, the signal of the La 3d region (not showed) is composed of the two typical La 3d 5/2 and La 3d 3/2 doublets at about 830–840 eV and 850–860 eV, respectively. Concerning the B-site species, the spectrum of the rLNA sample shows the Al 2p peak at 73.0 eV, the rLNT exhibits the Ti 2p 3/2 signal at 458.6 eV, whereas in the rLNF spectrum, the Fe 2p 3/2 signal display multiple contributions around 706, 709, and 711 eV (not showed). These binding energy values correspond to the presence of Al(III), Ti(IV), and Fe(II,III) species, indicating a highly interactive oxidic environment. Nickel analysis was performed using the Ni 3p region because part of the Ni 2p signal overlaps with La 3d 3/2. Deconvolution indicated the presence of metallic Ni in all reduced materials ( Table 3) since the spectra presented a signal at ∼66–67 eV [63]. Table 3 shows the percentage of Ni(0) determined from the deconvolutions (in brackets). Signals associated with oxidized species (∼68–70 eV) were also observed (Figure S5) [64], indicating incomplete reduction of Ni that might remain in the structure, thereby contributing to its stability, as observed by XRD. From the O 1 s core level spectra analysis, it was deduced that these same materials showed higher oxygen vacancy content, measured as the ratio of atomic content of adsorbed oxygen (Oads) to oxygen in the structure (Olatt) (Table 3 and Fig. 3). For that, the O 1 s spectra were deconvoluted into three peaks, one peak corresponding to bulk lattice oxygen (Olatt) located at ∼529.6 eV, another related to reactive surface oxygen species (Oads) about 531.0 eV, and the latter peak at ∼532.2 eV was associated to surface adsorbed molecules such as CO2 and H2O [65]. Table 3 shows the Oad/Olatt ratio obtained from the catalyst spectra. The results suggest that modifying the B site modifies the oxygen vacancy content. The catalysts show the following decreasing order in oxygen vacancy content: Fe> Ti > Al. This fact could be correlated with the degree of reducibility of these cations since these vacancies are generated from changes in oxidation states of the B-site species to stabilize the lattice. In addition, the analysis of Fe 2p spectral region suggests that Fe cation presented different oxidation states [66,67]. On the other hand, the metallic Ni species in the catalysts with Ti in the B-site displayed higher BE than those in the other catalysts (Table 3), denoting a stronger metal-support interaction. This observation is supported by the H2-TPR profiles (Figure S3). The rLNT catalyst exhibited two broad reduction peaks, one at high temperatures (∼531°C) and another at a lower temperature (∼325°C). The presence of this high-temperature signal suggests that a significant fraction of Ni species is strongly bonded to the oxide matrix, requiring higher energy for reduction. This behavior reinforces the existence of strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) in the Ti-containing catalyst. In contrast, the TPR profiles of rLNF and rLNA showed sharper and more intense reduction peaks at lower temperatures (386 and 345 °C, respectively), consistent with the presence of more weakly interacting Ni species, as also suggested by the lower BE values obtained from the XPS analysis. Concerning the quantitative surface analysis, it should be noted that the nominal atomic percentage content of Ni in the perovskites is 7.6 % (bulk content). According to the results obtained by XPS, the percentage of Ni exposed in the reduced catalysts (∼1–2.4 %) is lower than the nominal values. It varies slightly depending on the type of cation occupying the B site and the reduction temperature (Table 3). Besides, all catalysts exhibited a Ni/La+B ratio lower than 0.23 (total exsolution), the reduction temperature having a greater effect on the LNT system. The CO chemisorption results (Table 3) indicated that all catalysts exhibited low metal dispersion and metal area. These results were as expected, given that perovskites exhibited low specific surface area. Among the catalysts, rLNT750 showed the highest metal surface area, likely due to the higher specific surface area of the parent LNT perovskite. Furthermore, a further reduction in pretreatment temperature promoted Ni exsolution when the B-site cation was Ti, and the base perovskite presented a lager area. Conversely, when the B-site cation was Al, an increase in reduction temperature did not favor exsolution, as suggested by both the quantitative XPS and CO chemisorption results (Table 3). 3.2 Evaluation of catalytic activity in ESR for H2 production: B-site effect The effect of the B-site nature on the catalytic activity was evaluated in the ESR reaction at 500 °C and a 1:3 ethanol:water: molar ratio with the reduced perovskites (rLNB) and at low space velocity. It should be highlighted that the operating conditions were chosen to significantly suppress the reforming reaction and maximize the contact time between the reactants and the catalytic surface. The use of low space velocity and high residence time increases unwanted side reactions, including those leading to carbon deposition, which can contribute to catalyst deactivation. These conditions were designed to evaluate the resistance of the catalysts to deactivation caused by encapsulation of the active phase. The reaction performance without catalyst showed a conversion of ∼ 36 % and a negligible H2 yield. A screening of the conversion, H2 performance, and selectivity toward C1 compounds of catalysts prepared at different temperatures and precursors is shown in Fig. 4. The Fe catalyst reduced at 750 °C was not evaluated since the perovskite decomposed after heat treatment, as was shown in the previous section. As can be seen in Fig. 4 and the results summarised in Table ST1 of the supplementary material, almost all studied perovskites displayed high ethanol conversion and high H2 production and were selective to CO2, as expected in the overall ESR reaction. The catalysts that exhibited higher yields at H2 were the rLNA and rLNT catalysts (reduced at both temperatures), with yields between 40 % and 60 %, respectively. The rLNF500 catalyst showed a lower performance (∼ 20 %) despite demonstrating a high content of exposed Ni(0). This fact is probably associated with the low catalyst surface area. Regarding selectivity, no significant differences were observed in the C1 product distribution (CO2, CO, and CH4), while some differences were detected in the CO2/CO ratio. All catalysts (rLNB) would be promoting the WGS reaction (CO2/CO ratio > 1) with the rLNT750 catalyst presenting the highest ratio. This proposal is also supported by the fact that the H2/CO2 molar ratio found with the catalysts is higher than the stoichiometric one (H2/CO2 = 3) (see Table ST1). According to the results obtained, the investigation focused on identifying the catalysts that demonstrated optimal hydrogen performance in experiments related to the assessment of catalytic stability. Fig. 5 shows the TOS measurements during 24 h at the same reaction conditions described above for rLNT and rLNA catalysts reduced to 500 and 750°C. The rLNA500 and rLNT500 catalysts exhibited a progressive increase in ethylene content during the reaction, derived from ethanol dehydration (Eq. 3), whose presence indicates a possible catalyst deactivation by carbon formation and/or lack of ethylene reforming. Ethanol dehydration is one of the more critical reactions during the ethanol reforming reaction that drives carbon deposits and has been related to the type and concentration of acid sites in the material. The higher the strong acidity, the higher the ethylene formation. In turn, this can lead to catalyst deactivation by forming encapsulating carbon [19,20,68] due to ethylene polymerization (Eq. 13) on the catalyst surface through π-bonds. However, steam reforming could also transform ethylene into CO and H2 (Eq. 14) [20], which would be a more desirable reaction route. Therefore, the presence of this compound during the reaction points to a dehydration pathway, formation of carbon deposits, and lack of ethylene reforming. At the end of the reaction (1440 min), both catalysts presented a deactivation higher than 40 % regarding H2 production. (13) C 2 H 4 → C 2 H 4 n → Carbon deposits (14) C 2 H 4 + 2 H 2 O → 2 CO + 4 H 2 In addition, the presence of acetaldehyde, acetic acid, and acetone in the reaction products is indicative of increased catalyst deactivation, characterized by a loss of the capacity to break C-C bonds. This phenomenon has been previously reported [25,69]. These compounds can be produced by ethanol dehydrogenation (Eq. 2) and oxidation (Eq. 15), and acetaldehyde or ethanol condensation (Eqs. 6 and 16), respectively. In fact, both catalysts, rLNA500 and rLNT500, displayed an increase in acetaldehyde and a decrease in acetone as the reaction progressed (Figure S6), which coincided with the loss of activity. Acetone is recognized as an undesirable product in ESR, because its aldol condensation gives rise to diacetone alcohol, which can undergo dehydration to mesityl oxide (Eq. 17), whose oligomerization leads to the coke formation [25,68]. (15) CH 3 CH 2 OH + H 2 O → CH 3 COOH + 2 H 2 (16) 2 CH 3 CH 2 OH → CH 3 CO CH 3 + CO + 3 H 2 (17) 2 CH 3 CO CH 3 → ( CH 3 ) 2 C OH CH 2 CO CH 3 → ( CH 3 ) 2 C = CHCO CH 3 + H 2 O Conversely, the rLNA750 catalyst showed higher stability with 18 % deactivation at 1440 min of TOS (Fig. 5c). However, though this catalyst exhibited a low increase in the selectivity to ethylene, it also presented a substantial increase in the content of 2- and 3-carbon intermediates indicating loss of activity (Figure S6). Meanwhile, the rLNT750 catalyst showed no signs of deactivation. This catalyst exhibited sharp stability over 1440 min of TOS (Fig. 5d), with an H2 yield of around 50 % and a constant product distribution along the reaction (0 % deactivation). These results correlated with a low ethylene content and other intermediates on this catalyst (Figure S6). The ethanol conversion during all the experiments performed was high. These results agree with numerous experimental and theoretical studies reported in the literature. Thermodynamic analyses based on Gibbs free energy predict near-complete ethanol conversion starting from around 350 ºC [70]. while experimental studies conducted under various temperatures and space velocities also confirm ethanol's high reactivity and complete conversion under typical reforming conditions [71–76]. These findings highlight a known characteristic of ethanol as a reactant: its high reactivity and tendency to fully convert even at relatively low temperatures. The significant improvement in metal catalyst stability achieved using the exsolution method was illustrated by comparing the stability of a Ni catalyst prepared by the impregnation method, which is a widely used technique for synthesizing heterogeneous catalysts. For this purpose, a Ni catalyst supported on a LaTiO3 perovskite was synthesized by the wet impregnation method (10 % Ni/LaTiO3) and reduced at 750 °C. This impregnated catalyst exhibited an initial H2 yield of approximately 40 %, significantly lower than that of rLNT750. Moreover, it showed clear signs of deactivation during the 24 h TOS test, with a progressive decrease in hydrogen production and a notable increase in CH4 selectivity. After 15 h, the CH4 and CO selectivities become comparable, suggesting structural or chemical changes on the catalyst surface. The increase in C2H4 formation over time indicates enhanced carbon deposition by ethylene polymerization. The sharp deactivation was confirmed by the high amount of carbon deposited on the catalyst after 24 h of reaction, as evidences by TGA measurements (720.2 mg C/g cat after 24 h of reaction). These results confirm that the exsolved catalyst demonstrates superior stability and performance under reaction conditions that are prone to deactivation. 3.3 Long-term stability on Ni catalyst synthesized from LaNi0.38Ti0.62O3-δ perovskite. Effect on physical-chemical characteristics of catalyst Longer stability measurements were carried out on the rLNA750 and rLNT750 catalysts. The rLNA750 sample exhibited good stability, but after 50 h of reaction (Figure S8) it lost 24 % of the hydrogen yield and showed a slight decrease in ethanol conversion, indicating a loss of activity accompanied by an increase in ethylene content. In contrast, the rLNT750 catalyst showed very good stability over 100 h of reaction, as shown in Fig. 6. The conversion, product distribution, and H2 yield remained constant throughout the reaction. In addition, the selectivity to ethylene did not exceed 2 % at the end of the reaction, which clearly indicates that no deactivation occurred. Concerning the condensable products, they also remained constant over time, with low concentrations of these compounds compared to those obtained in 24-hour experiments. (Figure S6). Moreover, in rLNT750 perovskite, the presence of Ti in the B site could be promoting a higher metal-support interaction, which resulted in higher stability of the catalyst, as mentioned before [41,43–47] 3.4 Gasification capacity and reactivation of rLNT750 catalyst It is well known that mobile reticular oxygen ions in the catalysts facilitate the in-situ gasification of carbon deposits [77]. To evaluate the resistance to carbon deposition during the reaction, the rLNT750 catalyst was deactivated up to 50 % to simulate the effects of the deactivated catalyst. It was then subjected to a gasification test, which was carried out under thermal conditions to observe the catalyst's capacity for carbon deposit evolution without the influence of an external reactive gas. This allowed for a more accurate assessment of the catalyst's gasification capability. For this purpose, the production of CO and CO2 is detected during a thermal treatment from RT to 600 °C under a N2 flow to evaluate the catalyst's ability to react with the carbon deposited on its surface. As shown in Fig. 7, the CO2 signal appears at approximately 300 °C. It reaches a maximum at a temperature of 470 °C for both catalysts, which agrees with the results reported by Wu et al. [78]. For rLNT750 (Fig. 7a), CO increases significantly above 450 °C. The presence of both species demonstrates that carbon is being gasified at the expense of oxygen provided by the catalyst. In contrast, the rLNT500 catalyst (Fig. 7b) exhibits significantly lower concentrations of both species. On the other hand, as observed in Fig. 7a, after carbon gasification, the rLNT750 catalyst recovered almost its initial activity. In contrast, the rLNT500 recovered only 69 % of its initial activity after reactivation by gasification. It demonstrated a higher regeneration capacity of the LNT750 catalyst, which aligns with its higher stability observed at longer reaction times. These results confirm that rLNT750 exhibits a higher self-regeneration capacity through carbon gasification. This behavior is consistent with the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), which showed a lower amount of carbon deposited after 100 h of reaction compared to the amount detected after only 24 h. This indicates that part of the carbon is being gradually removed during the reaction, likely due to the intrinsic gasification activity of the catalyst under operating conditions. 3.5 Effect of operational conditions on catalytic performance of LNT catalyst The space velocity, reaction temperature, and water/ethanol feed ratio were studied to describe the effect of different operating conditions on the product distribution. It is known that increasing water/ethanol ratio in steam reforming can promote reforming reactions [79,80]. As illustrated in Fig. 8a, an increase in the water/ethanol ratio leads to higher levels of H2 and CO2, while CO and CH4 decrease. This phenomenon can be attributed to the thermodynamic promotion of CH4-steam-reforming and WGS reactions with increasing steam [79]. This trend has been observed in other investigations [21,81,82]. When the rLNT750 catalyst was evaluated at different temperatures (Fig. 8b), with water/ethanol molar ratio fixed to 3/1, it was observed that the operating temperature significantly influenced different reaction pathways in the process. At higher temperatures (600 and 700 ºC), an increase in H2 yield (reaching almost 70 %) is observed, accompanied by a higher CO selectivity and a lower selectivity to CH4 and CO2, probably due to the promoting of CH4 decomposition and/or CH4 reforming that are favored above 550 ºC as shown in the theoretical thermodynamic study presented in Figure S9. In addition, the high selectivity observed to CO and CO2 reduction could be explained by favoring rWGS, as previously reported [83]. In contrast, at 500 ºC, a higher selectivity to CO2 and a lower amount of CO were observed, owing to the WGS reaction. At the lowest temperature evaluated, 400 ºC, the lowest yield to H2 was observed, while the selectivity to the products had the following order CO2>CH4>CO. These results could indicate the favoring of the Boudouard reaction and CO-methanation, which are exothermic reactions promoted at low-temperature. In fact, at this temperature, the catalyst exhibited faster deactivation. The influence of space velocity on the ESR product distribution is shown in Fig. 8c. The temperature was kept constant (500 ºC) and a stoichiometric H2O/EtOH ratio of 3 was used for the test. As seen in that figure, the GHSV affected the product selectivity, as previously reported [21] [84,85]. Increasing GHSV decreased the H2-yield and CO2 selectivity, while CO increased and CH4 remained relatively constant, with 19475 mL gcat−1 h−1 being the optimal GHSV to have the highest H2 yield. Moreover, by performing the CESR reaction using the rLNT750 catalyst at the highest space velocity, a high hydrogen yield was achieved when the H2O:Ethanol molar ratio was increased to 6. Comparative results are shown in the supplementary material, Table ST3 (Supplementary material). 3.6 Characterisation of post-reaction catalysts The catalysts were characterized after catalytic activity measurement at 24 and 100 h by TGA-TPO, Raman, XPS, and TEM. The carbon deposited after ESR test at 500°C and a H2O:EtOH ratio of 3 was quantified by TGA-TPO measurement, and the results are displayed in Fig. 9 and Table 4. The TGA/DTG profiles of the spent catalysts exhibit weight loss (%), mainly resulting from the oxidation of carbon species deposited on the catalysts. The first mass loss observed up to 120 °C can be attributed to removing H2O. Mass losses can be observed at higher temperatures, which could be associated with the presence of oxidized and adsorbed molecules on the surface, whose combustion is expected in this temperature range. However, this signal is coupled with a mass gain that can be attributed to the oxidation of the metallic nickel phase. At higher temperatures, the combustion of deposited carbon species is expected. In addition, the morphology of deposited carbon can be assessed according to the gasification temperature, such as amorphous carbon (sp 2 C-atoms 300–450 °C), filamentous carbon (450–550 °C), and graphitic carbon (sp 3 C-atoms > 600 °C) [86,87]. All catalysts exhibited bands between 500 and 630 °C, which could be related to the formation of nanotubular carbon with some degree of graphitization. In this regard, it is worth noting that the combustion temperatures of the deposited carbon phases may differ and be lower than those reported in the literature, since catalysts containing lanthanum and oxygen vacancies promote soot combustion reactions [88]. However, catalysts reduced at a lower temperature showed a lower mass loss temperature, possibly attributable to amorphous carbon deposits. The carbon nature is related to the reaction pathways promoted by the catalysts; thus, polymerization of C2 intermediates could lead to the amorphous carbon formation (Eqs. 15,16,17). These intermediates were detected along the reaction in the catalysts reduced at 500 ºC, suggesting that amorphous carbon may have been promoted on these catalysts. Meanwhile, in the catalysts reduced at 750 ºC, where a very low presence of C2 compounds was observed, the deposited carbon could come mainly from CH4 decomposition (Eq. 11). However, all catalysts showed a very low level of carbon deposition (Table 4) compared to other studies reported for the same reaction [28,89,90]. Even at 100 h of TOS for the rLNT750 catalyst, the amount of deposited carbon was minimal, which may be related to favoring carbon gasification throughout the reaction, as previously mentioned [28,77,90]. Moreover, the gasification test (Fig. 7a) showed the regenerative capacity of the rLNT750 catalyst. This ability is directly related to the formation of oxygen vacancies, which were determined using the Oads/Olatt from O 1 s XPS spectra (Table 3). As shown in Table 4, the number of oxygen vacancies increases with thermal aging of the catalysts. The highest proportion was achieved after 100 h of reaction on Ti catalysts (rLNT750), which is consistent with the results reported by Al-Fatesh et al. [86]. This behavior has been attributed to the back-spillover of O2− ions on the surface Ni particles with abundant oxygen vacancies in the vicinity of Ni. Thus, the O2− back-spillover could favor the gasifying of the carbon deposits during the reaction [86,91], as was demonstrated for the rLNT750 catalyst. This catalyst was reactivated at 60 % under an N2 flow, which avoids oxidation of the metallic phase and the subsequent reduction stage. Fig. 10 depicts the Raman spectra of the used catalysts after the 24 and 100 h of TOS. In these spectra, two peaks were observed. The peak at 1340 cm−1 corresponds to disordered carbon (D band), and the other is related to graphitic carbon structure (G band) located at 1580 cm−1. The IG/ID ratio indicated a certain degree of graphitization of the deposited carbon in all catalysts except for the Fe-containing catalyst. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) measurements ( Fig. 11) carried out on catalysts with the greatest catalytic performance and stability (rLNT750 and rLNA750) showed that both catalysts tend to form crystalline carbon allotrope structures in the shape of filamentous carbon, in agreement with the TGA results. However, in the Al catalyst (rLNA750) case, nickel particles were pushed off support to the filament top (whisker) [92], exhibiting a slight deactivation of the catalyst after 24 h of reaction. A similar phenomenon was observed for rLNA500 and rLNT500, where the presence of structured filamentous carbon also caused the detachment of the metal particles from the support. In addition, TEM and TGA analyses revealed the presence of amorphous carbon in all three catalysts (rLNA500, rLNT500, and rLNA750). This type of carbon is well known for its strong encapsulating effect, which can lead to severe catalyst deactivation by blocking active sites. On the contrary, although the Ti catalyst shows filamentous carbon formation, its growth did not detach the metal particles from the support. This result could be attributed to the enhanced metal-support interaction on this catalyst, as suggested by the H2-TPR and XPS results, which prevents the particle from separating from the support. This effect has also been reported for other Ti-based catalysts, formed after high-temperature reduction treatment (>500 °C), leading to the formation of Ti3+ ions and oxygen vacancies [93]. These vacancies play a crucial role in promoting gasification pathways by activating and transferring oxygen atoms (O*). Specifically, the presence of oxygen vacancies (Ti3+) at high temperatures facilitates the dissociation of H2O molecules, generating reactive OH* and O* species that participate in the oxidation of carbonaceous intermediates formed through the decomposition of CH4 and C2H4 (Eqs. 6 and 7) [94,95]. In this work, XPS analysis suggested the presence of Ti3+/Ti4+. The Ti 2p 3/2 signal is wide and asymmetric, and it can be deconvolved into two contributions, as shown in Figure S10. This mechanism shifts the reaction pathway towards continuous carbon removal, which improves the catalyst's self-regeneration capacity and limits carbon accumulation during the reaction. Overall, the deactivation observed in rLNA750, rLNA500, and rLNT500 catalysts can be directly associated with the damage caused by the deposition of filamentous carbon, which weakens the contact between metal particles and the support. This effect was not observed in rLNT750, further supporting the idea that strong metal–support interactions play a key role in preserving catalyst integrity and long-term performance. The results obtained by XPS for the C/La surface atomic ratio (Table 4), corroborate the quantitative results observed by TGA. On the other hand, from the C 1 s core level spectra analysis, it was observed that carbons of different nature coexist on the catalyst surface. Figure S11a (Supplementary material) shows the C 1 s core level spectra of the rLNT750 fresh and post-reaction catalyst samples. The relative increase in the concentration of the most surface-interacting carbon species is noticeable. Due to the B.E. of these species it cannot be ruled out that they are oxidised species. The information presented in the previous paragraphs is consistent with the results obtained from the XPS analyses. Figure S11 in the supplementary material shows the C 1 s spectra recorded at different reaction times for the most stable catalysts, the LNT750 and LNTA750 samples. These results indicate that, in addition to changes in surface carbon content throughout the reaction, the nature of the carbon species also evolves, as evidenced by the increasing contribution of signals corresponding to more strongly interacting carbon species, located at higher binding energy values. It cannot be ruled out that signals associated with C–O bonds also appear. This interpretation is supported by the O 1 s spectrum, where an increase in high B.E. components (∼533–534.5 eV) was observed. The increase and/or appearance of these signals could be associated with the presence of oxygen-bound carbon species. Additionally, with increasing reaction time, the binding energies of the elements in the perovskite also change. Figures S12, S13, and S14 in the supplementary material show how the binding energies of the O 1 s, La 3d, and Ti 2p signals shift toward higher B.E. values, indicating a significant increase in the interaction among the surface elements. In the case of titanium, it is possible that the oxidation state of this cation may have changed toward a more oxidized state. Despite the generation of carbon deposits on the surface, which leads to a slight decrease in the amount of exposed Ni, and the likelihood of redox processes and changes in the oxidation state of the surface Ni (see Table 3), the rLNA750 and rLNTi750 catalysts, particularly the Ti-containing catalyst, demonstrate consistent activity over extended reaction times. 4 Conclusions Highly stable Ni catalysts from perovskite-like structures were successfully synthesized using the exsolution method. The influence of the nature of the B-site on the stability of the evaluated catalysts was highlighted. The catalysts with Ti and Al in the B-site reduced at the highest temperature showed higher stability over the reaction time. The rLNT750 catalyst showed no signs of deactivation during 100 h of reaction with a very low carbon deposition rate, which could be attributed to its higher initial specific surface area, gasification capacity, oxygen vacancy content, and a stronger metal-support interaction. Both catalysts (Al and Ti) exhibited filamentous carbon formation. However, only the Al-containing catalyst had Ni particles detached from the support, resulting in a slight deactivation. of the catalyst. In contrast, although the Ti catalyst showed filamentous carbon formation, its growth did not detach the metal particles from the support. This could be attributed to the higher metal-support interaction on this catalyst, which prevents the particle from being removed from the support. Additionally, TEM analysis of the rLNA500 and rLNT500 catalysts revealed that filamentous carbon structures (whiskers) were responsible for the mechanical removal of Ni nanoparticles from the support, which is likely one of the main causes of deactivation at lower reduction temperatures. These findings reinforce the importance of optimizing the metal-support interaction and reduction conditions to suppress metal detachment and improve catalyst stability. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen production from catalytic steam reforming of biomass compounds represents an alternative to the growing demand for new renewable energy sources. In this work, highly stable Ni catalysts synthesized by exsolution method from LaNi0.38B0.62O3 ±δ-type perovskite with different cations at the B site (B= Ti, Al, Fe) are described. These catalysts were evaluated in hydrogen production from steam reforming reaction using ethanol, a typical oxygenated molecule derived from biomass that is commonly used for this reaction. XRD analyses confirmed the formation of perovskite-like structures and the exsolution of Ni metallic particles after reduction treatment. In addition, XPS results demonstrated surface enrichment of Ni(0). The catalysts that exhibited greater stability in 24 h tests were those reduced at 750 °C, from LaNi0.38Ti0.62O3-δ and LaNi0.38Al0.62O3-δ perovskites, the catalyst with Ti in B-site being the most stable with no signs of deactivation throughout the whole reaction. Moreover, this catalyst maintained a constant activity during 100 h of TOS, a very low carbon deposit formation rate, and showed a high capacity to remove carbon deposits via gasification, compared to reported catalysts not based on noble metals. The high stability observed in this catalyst was related to the strong metal-support interaction generated during the metal catalyst preparation process from the exsolution method.
